Key Arguments: The bill undermines freedom of speech and fails to address the complexities of misinformation and disinformation.
The bill infringes on the rights to freedom of thought, conscience, religion, opinion, and expression as outlined in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.
The government should focus on ensuring accountability and transparency rather than controlling information.
The bill could prevent access to truth and the ability to protest government mistakes and bad policies.
The bill should apply to the Australian Government and their funded media, which are perceived as sources of misinformation.
The language of the bill should focus on 'causing harm and death' rather than 'posing a threat'.
The bill is seen as a threat to the preferred narrative by the government.
The author does not consent to the Sustainable Development Goals and believes they are detrimental to Australia.
Notable Quotes: This bill undermines the fundamental principles of freedom of speech and fails to address the complexities surrounding misinformation and disinformation.
It will also remove the ability to access truth and protest Government mistakes, bad policy and deprive Australians of their inalienable rights.
The ACMA legislation is entirely indefensible. I do not consent.
